required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Safety and Efficacy Study of Prograf in the Prevention of Erectile Dysfunction After Radical Prostatectomy
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Study to Assess the Safety and Efficacy of Prograf (Tacrolimus, FK 506) for the Prevention of Erectile Dysfunction Following Bilateral Nerve-sparing Radical Prostatectomy

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of the study is to compare the safety and effectiveness of Prograf in the prevention of erectile dysfunction in men after a radical prostatectomy.

detailed_description.textblock: The purpose of the study is to compare the safety and efficacy of Prograf versus placebo in the prevention of erectile dysfunction in men after a bilateral nerve-sparing radical prostatectomy.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Erectile Function Domain Score Between Treated and Untreated Groups
primary_outcome.description: Erectile function was assessed using the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) questionnaire, which consists of 15 questions. The erectile function domain score is calculated as a sum of scores from questions 1-5 and 15. A clinically meaningful difference is 5 points. The scores range from 1 to 30 points where a higher score indicates better erectile function. Normal erectile function is defined as greater than or equal to 24 points.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Patients Achieving Normal Spontaneous Erectile Function as Measured by the Erectile Function (EF) Domain Score
secondary_outcome.description: Erectile function was assessed using the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) questionnaire, which consists of 15 questions. The erectile function domain score is calculated as a sum of scores from questions 1-5 and 15. A clinically meaningful difference is 5 points. The scores range from 1 to 30 points where a higher score indicates better erectile function. Normal erectile function is defined as greater than or equal to 24 points. Percentages represent the proportions of participants who achieved normal erectile function at any time during the 24 months.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time Taken to Achieve Normalization of the Erectile Function (EF) Domain Score
secondary_outcome.description: Erectile function was assessed using the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) questionnaire, which consists of 15 questions. The EF domain score is calculated as a sum of scores from questions 1-5 and 15. A clinically meaningful difference is 5 points. Scores range from 1-30 points where a higher score indicates better erectile function. Normal erectile function is defined as greater than or equal to 24 points.Time to achieve normalization of the EF domain score was calculated based on the date of the assessment during which the EF domain score was first greater than or equal to 24.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Patients Considered Successful Responders to Impotence Medications
secondary_outcome.description: Patients were identified as successful responders if they answered affirmatively in the Patient Sexual Encounter Diary regarding successful sexual intercourse after using impotence medication.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Achieve Response to Impotence Medications
secondary_outcome.description: Time to achieve response to impotence medication was calculated based on the date of the assessment during which the first successful response was recorded. The specific date of the actual response is not reflected; only that it occurred since the previous study visit.

secondary_outcome.measure: Continence Level as Quantified by Part I of the Prostate Health-Related Quality of Life Questionnaire
secondary_outcome.description: Part 1 Urinary Function- Prostate Health-Related Quality-of-Life (QOL) Questionnaire consists of 16 questions asking patients about their continence and urinary habits over the previous four weeks. The responses to all 16 of these questions were added together to calculate an overall score for urinary function. The minimum possible score is 16 and the maximum possible score is 79. A higher score indicates a lower continence level.

arm_group.description: Preoperatively: Tacrolimus 2 mg oral daily from 4 to 10 days prior to surgery through hospital discharge; Postoperatively: Tacrolimus 3 mg oral daily at time of hospital discharge through 6 months of follow up.

Preoperatively: Matching placebo oral daily from 4 to 10 days prior to surgery through hospital discharge; Postoperatively: Matching placebo oral daily at time of hospital discharge through 6 months of follow up.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male scheduled to undergo bilateral nerve sparing radical prostatectomy for prostate cancer.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient is > 65 years of age
- Patient has been diagnosed with Type 1 or Type 2 diabetes
- Patient is actively smoking on a daily basis

group.title: Tacrolimus
group.description: Preoperatively: Tacrolimus 2 mg oral daily from 4 to 10 days prior to surgery through hospital discharge; Postoperatively: Tacrolimus 3 mg oral daily at time of hospital discharge through 6 months of follow up.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Preoperatively: Matching placebo oral daily from 4 to 10 days prior to surgery through hospital discharge; Postoperatively: Matching placebo oral daily at time of hospital discharge through 6 months of follow up.

participants_list.participants: 3 patients withdrew: 2 prior to surgery and study drug; 1 took study drug but did not have surgery
4 patients withdrew: all prior to surgery and study drug

group.title: Tacrolimus
group.description: Preoperatively: Tacrolimus 2 mg oral daily from 4 to 10 days prior to surgery through hospital discharge; Postoperatively: Tacrolimus 3 mg oral daily at time of hospital discharge through 6 months of follow up.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Preoperatively: Matching placebo oral daily from 4 to 10 days prior to surgery through hospital discharge; Postoperatively: Matching placebo oral daily at time of hospital discharge through 6 months of follow up.

outcome.title: Erectile Function Domain Score Between Treated and Untreated Groups
outcome.description: Erectile function was assessed using the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) questionnaire, which consists of 15 questions. The erectile function domain score is calculated as a sum of scores from questions 1-5 and 15. A clinically meaningful difference is 5 points. The scores range from 1 to 30 points where a higher score indicates better erectile function. Normal erectile function is defined as greater than or equal to 24 points.
outcome.population: The number of participants analyzed represents Full Analysis Set (FAS), which is defined as participants evaluated for Efficacy and Safety. Only participants with complete IIEF questionnaire data at 18 months are included in the calculation.

group.title: Tacrolimus
group.description: Preoperatively: Tacrolimus 2 mg oral daily from 4 to 10 days prior to surgery through hospital discharge; Postoperatively: Tacrolimus 3 mg oral daily at time of hospital discharge through 6 months of follow up.

measure.title: Erectile Function Domain Score Between Treated and Untreated Groups
measure.description: Erectile function was assessed using the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) questionnaire, which consists of 15 questions. The erectile function domain score is calculated as a sum of scores from questions 1-5 and 15. A clinically meaningful difference is 5 points. The scores range from 1 to 30 points where a higher score indicates better erectile function. Normal erectile function is defined as greater than or equal to 24 points.
measure.population: The number of participants analyzed represents Full Analysis Set (FAS), which is defined as participants evaluated for Efficacy and Safety. Only participants with complete IIEF questionnaire data at 18 months are included in the calculation.

analysis.groups_desc: A group sequential design using the O'Brien and Fleming stopping rule will require 58 evaluable patients per group to detect a 5-point difference in the Erectile Function domain of the IIEF with a power of 80% and an overall significance level of 5%.

outcome.title: Percentage of Patients Achieving Normal Spontaneous Erectile Function as Measured by the Erectile Function (EF) Domain Score
outcome.description: Erectile function was assessed using the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) questionnaire, which consists of 15 questions. The erectile function domain score is calculated as a sum of scores from questions 1-5 and 15. A clinically meaningful difference is 5 points. The scores range from 1 to 30 points where a higher score indicates better erectile function. Normal erectile function is defined as greater than or equal to 24 points. Percentages represent the proportions of participants who achieved normal erectile function at any time during the 24 months.
outcome.population: The number of participants analyzed represents Full Analysis Set (FAS), which is defined as participants evaluated for Efficacy and Safety.

The erectile function domain score is calculated as a sum of scores from questions 1-5 and 15. A clinically meaningful difference is 5 points. The scores range from 1 to 30 points where a higher score indicates better erectile function. Normal erectile function is defined as greater than or equal to 24 points. Percentages represent the proportions of participants who achieved normal erectile function at any time during the 24 months.

outcome.description: Erectile function was assessed using the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) questionnaire, which consists of 15 questions. The EF domain score is calculated as a sum of scores from questions 1-5 and 15. A clinically meaningful difference is 5 points. Scores range from 1-30 points where a higher score indicates better erectile function. Normal erectile function is defined as greater than or equal to 24 points.Time to achieve normalization of the EF domain score was calculated based on the date of the assessment during which the EF domain score was first greater than or equal to 24.

measure.title: Time Taken to Achieve Normalization of the Erectile Function (EF) Domain Score
measure.description: Erectile function was assessed using the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) questionnaire, which consists of 15 questions. The EF domain score is calculated as a sum of scores from questions 1-5 and 15. A clinically meaningful difference is 5 points. Scores range from 1-30 points where a higher score indicates better erectile function. Normal erectile function is defined as greater than or equal to 24 points.Time to achieve normalization of the EF domain score was calculated based on the date of the assessment during which the EF domain score was first greater than or equal to 24.
measure.population: The number of participants analyzed represents Full Analysis Set (FAS), which is defined as participants evaluated for Efficacy and Safety. Only participants who achieved normal erectile function are included in the calculation.

outcome.title: Percentage of Patients Considered Successful Responders to Impotence Medications
outcome.description: Patients were identified as successful responders if they answered affirmatively in the Patient Sexual Encounter Diary regarding successful sexual intercourse after using impotence medication.
outcome.population: The number of participants analyzed represents Full Analysis Set (FAS), which is defined as participants evaluated for Efficacy and Safety. Only participants who used any impotence medications were included in the calculation.

group.description: Preoperatively: Tacrolimus 2 mg oral daily from 4 to 10 days prior to surgery through hospital discharge; Postoperatively: Tacrolimus 3 mg oral daily at time of hospital discharge through 6 months of follow up.

measure.title: Percentage of Patients Considered Successful Responders to Impotence Medications
measure.description: Patients were identified as successful responders if they answered affirmatively in the Patient Sexual Encounter Diary regarding successful sexual intercourse after using impotence medication.
measure.population: The number of participants analyzed represents Full Analysis Set (FAS), which is defined as participants evaluated for Efficacy and Safety. Only participants who used any impotence medications were included in the calculation.

outcome.title: Time to Achieve Response to Impotence Medications
outcome.description: Time to achieve response to impotence medication was calculated based on the date of the assessment during which the first successful response was recorded. The specific date of the actual response is not reflected; only that it occurred since the previous study visit.
outcome.population: The number of participants analyzed represents Full Analysis Set (FAS), which is defined as participants evaluated for Efficacy and Safety. Only participants who had a successful response to impotence medications were included in the calculations.

group.title: Tacrolimus
group.description: Preoperatively: Tacrolimus 2 mg oral daily from 4 to 10 days prior to surgery through hospital discharge; Postoperatively: Tacrolimus 3 mg oral daily at time of hospital discharge through 6 months of follow up.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Preoperatively: Matching placebo oral daily from 4 to 10 days prior to surgery through hospital discharge; Postoperatively: Matching placebo oral daily at time of hospital discharge through 6 months of follow up.

measure.title: Time to Achieve Response to Impotence Medications
measure.description: Time to achieve response to impotence medication was calculated based on the date of the assessment during which the first successful response was recorded. The specific date of the actual response is not reflected; only that it occurred since the previous study visit.
measure.population: The number of participants analyzed represents Full Analysis Set (FAS), which is defined as participants evaluated for Efficacy and Safety. Only participants who had a successful response to impotence medications were included in the calculations.

outcome.title: Continence Level as Quantified by Part I of the Prostate Health-Related Quality of Life Questionnaire
outcome.description: Part 1 Urinary Function- Prostate Health-Related Quality-of-Life (QOL) Questionnaire consists of 16 questions asking patients about their continence and urinary habits over the previous four weeks. The responses to all 16 of these questions were added together to calculate an overall score for urinary function. The minimum possible score is 16 and the maximum possible score is 79. A higher score indicates a lower continence level.
outcome.population: The number of participants analyzed represents Full Analysis Set (FAS), which is defined as participants evaluated for Efficacy and Safety. Only participants with a Prostate Health-Related QOL questionnaire at 24 months were included in the calculation.

measure.description: Part 1 Urinary Function- Prostate Health-Related Quality-of-Life (QOL) Questionnaire consists of 16 questions asking patients about their continence and urinary habits over the previous four weeks. The responses to all 16 of these questions were added together to calculate an overall score for urinary function. The minimum possible score is 16 and the maximum possible score is 79. A higher score indicates a lower continence level.
measure.population: The number of participants analyzed represents Full Analysis Set (FAS), which is defined as participants evaluated for Efficacy and Safety. Only participants with a Prostate Health-Related QOL questionnaire at 24 months were included in the calculation.

reported_events.time_frame: SAEs and AEs as defined below were collected through month 6.
reported_events.desc: Serious Adverse Events possibly related to study drug were collected. The only other Adverse Events collected were those associated with study drug dose changes. Subjects who experienced an Adverse Event with the same preferred term multiple times were only counted once.

group.title: Tacrolimus
group.description: Preoperatively: Tacrolimus 2 mg oral daily from 4 to 10 days prior to surgery through hospital discharge; Postoperatively: Tacrolimus 3 mg oral daily at time of hospital discharge through 6 months of follow up.

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Institute and/or Principal Investigator may publish trial data generated at their specific study site after Sponsor publication of the multi-center data. Sponsor must receive a siteâ€™s manuscript at least 30 days prior to publication to ensure that no confidential information of Sponsor is included in the document.
